petitioner.name: PLEASANT GROVE CITY, UTAH, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 07-665, Pleasant Grove City v. Summum. Mr. Sekulow.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Sekulow, you're really just picking your poison, aren't you? I mean, the more you say that the monument is Government speech to get out of the first, free speech -- the Free Speech Clause, the more it seems to me you're walking into a trap under the Establishment Clause. If it's Government speech, it may not present a free speech problem, but what is the Government doing speaking -- supporting the Ten Commandments?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I don't want to interrupt your answer to the Chief Justice because I think it's critical, critical to your argument. As a procedural matter, I thought that the Establishment Clause issue was raised in the initial complaint. Are you taking the position it's now waived or something?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It was under the State?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If you prevail, the action should be dismissed, as far as you're concerned?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Then getting back to the Chief Justice's point, it does seem to me that if you say it's Government speech that in later cases, including the case of the existing monument, you're going to say it's Government speech and you have an Establishment Clause problem. I don't know if -- I'm not saying it would necessarily be resolved one way or the other, but it certainly raises - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- an Establishment Clause problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I suppose it depends on what the Government speech consists of, what it is the Government is saying about the Ten Commandments. If the Government is saying the Ten Commandments are the word of God that's one thing, and if the Government is saying the Ten Commandments are an important part of our national heritage, that's something else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you have to - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Did the NEA -- Finley v. NEA, the Court didn't treat that as Government speech.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Or am I -- is that the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Before we get -- before we get away from the Government, the Establishment Clause, you said, well, Van Orden answered that, but did it? Because you don't have here a 40-year history of this monument being there, and nobody seems to be troubled by it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think 38 is the cut-off point.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Sekulow - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- when you come upon this, if somebody comes upon this monument in the park, how are they supposed to tell whether it's Government speech or private speech?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In the context of all other lawgivers. This is a stand-alone Ten Commandments and you don't see, I don't think, anywhere "I am the Lord thy God." That's not shown.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is this a challenge to the Ten Commandments monument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought this case did not involve an Establishment Clause challenge. Why are we

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Mr. Sekulow, can I just ask: At what point in the litigation did you first raise the Government speech argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Isn't the tough -- isn't the tough issue here not so much whether there is Government speech. I will assume and I do indeed assume that there is. Isn't the tough issue here the claim that there is -- is in fact a mixture, that it is both Government and private. And the argument for its continuing to be private speech I take it is simply the Eagles identification with the presentation and their espousal of what the monument says. How -- how do you think we ought to deal with the mixture issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: They probably are, but most of them -- and you correct me if I'm wrong here. But I don't suppose that most of them -- most of them contain as part of -- in a prominent place in the monument itself contain the statement that, you know, this is the gift of or the position of or what-not of X, Y or Z, whereas this monument does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: We may have more cases coming.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But tell me, what is the criterion that we should use to decide what the significance of the private identification is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If that -- if we accept that there is Government speech, I think Justice Souter's question is isn't this really the Government endorsement of the Eagles' message? I mean, the Eagles are all over this monument, their symbol of the eagle, and the Eagles want it to be known that this is their monument. Indeed, I think in Van Orden wasn't the -- in the district court there, wasn't the statement, well, this -- Texas did this in recognition of the good work that the Eagles do in preventing -- - help try to prevent juvenile delinquency.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, if it does, it changes it, as I understand your answer, by eliminating the private aspect of the speech. So that your real answer to me is it's not a mixture.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And there ceases to be a mixture the moment the Government accepts it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Can I ask you question that's kind of in the background of the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Assume you didn't have the policy that you do have, but it was perfectly clear that the city decided not to put up this monument because it disagreed with the message of the monument. Whether you call it Government speech or private speech, would that be permissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But, Justice Stevens's question is important, maybe not for your case but for other cases. We are deciding this for other cases to arise, and why isn't he correct that if you don't like the message then that raises a content-based claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it doesn't seem to me that you have to make the Government speech argument for you to make the argument that you just made.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So the city, in effect, if the city says, we are going to have a designated ten-acre field in which anybody can put up a monument, but you can't because we don't like your message, there's a First Amendment problem. But if the city hides the ball in effect and says in effect, we'll - - we'll let monuments be placed on -- we will accept monuments from people who want to place them on our property if the monuments have some kind of an arguable historical connection or a connection with people with long association with the community, as long as they have that sort of criterion in mind then they can select any way they want to?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It goes to the same thing, doesn't it? I mean, whether it's the Government stating the message or whether it's the Government creating a limited public forum for the presentation of only those messages that it thinks are important, it comes to the same thing, doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Let me ask you a question to make sure I understand your position. It would have been permissible for the city to say, our park it filled with monuments and we are only going to let those in who convey messages that we agree with?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: If that's a policy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But really, in this case sort of the debate as to whether the policy justifications for the monument are a sham are not are really irrelevant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Even if it's a Government forum for private speech, I think it's the same thing. You're defining -- you define the forum to include only those -- the forum is putting up monuments. You just put up those monuments that agree with the message.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And the same question Justice Stevens had, just to tack onto his question here, your answer was: Oh, well, the Government owns it. Suppose the Government says: We will accept ownership only if we agree with the message. That just puts his question. I think the ownership argument is - - is not an answer to the Justice's question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Nothing could be a more obvious control of the message than the criterion that says we will decide in -- in determining to accept it or not, we will decide on the basis of whether we agree with the message. That is control with a vengeance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, they -- they do in the example Justice Kennedy just raised and the example that I just raised. The Eagles come along say: Here's the monument; take it; it's all yours.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And the -- the Government says: Okay, we'll take the Eagles monument. We will not on identical terms take the Summum monument because we disagree with the message. At the point they make the decision they don't own anything. What they are doing is controlling, in your words, and they are controlling on the basis of agreement with the message. Why isn't that a First Amendment violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But we've got -- we've got to shut our eyes to the period prior to the moment title passes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Does that mean if we engage in viewpoint discrimination for three decades, we are home free?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It wouldn't be a speaker on your view until it takes control of the monument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But those are cases in which, to begin with, the Government is engaging in -- a process of, in effect, sponsoring speech. And here we -- we have not, I think, reached the point in which the public park is to be analogized either with a publication or a magazine or -- or grants to -- to the arts.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Sekulow. Mr. Joseffer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can't there be a situation where the Government does create a monument that is a - - a limited public forum? Let's take the example that you just gave, the Vietnam War Memorial. I presume the Government could not refuse to have the names of certain deceased soldiers on that monument because it disagreed with certain ideas that they had espoused at one point or another.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What's the answer to Justice Alito's question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, supposing the Government in the Vietnam Memorial decided not to put up the names of any homosexual soldiers. Would that be permissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That seems to be the problem here. And what I have in this is the -- the problem I have is that we seem to be applying these subcategories in a very absolute way. Why can't we call this what it is -- it's a mixture of private speech with Government decisionmaking -- and ask the question, as we do in election cases, is the restriction proportionate to a legitimate objective? I know how you're going to answer that question. You're going to say: Of course, it is. But what's interesting me is, are we bound in these cases to apply what I think of as an artificial kind of conceptual framework or are we free to ask what seems to me to be at the heart of the matter? The answer to Justice Stevens's hypothetically is: Of course the Government can't do that because it's disproportionate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I didn't get the answer. Did you - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So what is the answer to the -- what is the answer to Justice Stevens's hypothetical? What is the answer to the homosexual hypothetical? What is the answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because that tests the theory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me the Government could disfavor homosexuality just as it could disfavor abortion, just as it can disfavor a number of other things that in -- in many States people are free to do. The Government can disfavor all of it, can't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why is that the answer to the -- the question? Why isn't the answer to the question that monuments generally are not -- the erection of monuments generally are not a forum? There is a fundamental difference between the speaker's corner in the park where anybody can speak and a permanent monument that takes up space, presumably limited public space. And if you have the unusual situation where you are have a monument that is really analogous to a forum, then the forum analysis would be applicable. But to apply it to something like the Washington Monument or the Jefferson Memorial is ridiculous.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But suppose they only accept Democrats who are sculptors, and they reject all the Republicans?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, what in the First Amendment -- are you saying the First Amendment would not stop that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, under the Equal Protection Clause would -- if you wrote an Equal Protection Clause opinion, you would end up saying it's content-based. That's the First Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I don't think that can you avoid the hard part by saying, oh, other amendments of the Constitution might apply. The heart of the question is whether the Government may discriminate based on content, and that's a First Amendment question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's not only absolutely entitled, it has to do so. It -- it has no choice, does it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You can't run a museum if you have to accept everything, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does the law always require us to adopt an all-or-nothing position? Aren't there some extreme cases indicated by the hypothetical where the First Amendment does enter in? Do we have to decide this case that it's all or nothing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It would be -- the trouble - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I see your point, but the trouble with that as an argument here is the private part of the speech is just as much chiseled in stone as the public part. So it's not going to go away at the end of the day, and there isn't any way that the Government in effect can engage in the gesture of saying all private speech is treated the same way, whatever way that might be. So we've got a -- we've got a -- we've got a more difficult problem here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What you are, in effect, saying -- and this may be -- I don't mean I think this is necessarily the wrong answer -- but you're, in effect, saying, yes, you can find instances of Government speech in which there is clearly a -- a private identification consistent with it, but the only appropriate analysis is the analysis for government speech. You can't have it both ways, you've got to pick one or the other; and it is -- it is the Government aspect which controls the First Amendment purposes. That, I take it, is your answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: There is nothing unusual about it, but we haven't had this kind of a challenge before. So, I -- I guess it still rests on you to say why should we submerge the private part to the Government part. There may be a very good reason, but I want to know what your reason is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, maybe they can't do it in museums, either. I mean, yes, we've been doing this for a couple of hundred years, but maybe we've been wrong all along and maybe the Government can't run museums. It's possible, right? It's a brave new world.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Harris.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say in a public forum. I mean, that sort of begs the question. I mean, that - - that encapulates your -- your -- encapsulates your answer. Has the -- has the city allowed anybody to put up a monument there willy-nilly? I mean, a public forum, as you know, we can have praise in the park, we can have protest. Anybody can do it, so long as you get a license and you're not interfering with some other group. That's a public forum. Has this city said anybody can put up a monument in this park?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's a public forum for some things. Is it a public forum for everything? It may be a public forum for processions, for parades. But it is a public -- is it a public forum for anybody constructing a monument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Those are time, place, and manner regulations, with which we are all familiar. But my concern is that this -- this case is an example of the tyrannies -- of the tyranny of labels. Because it's a public forum, as Justice Scalia indicated, for parades, for protests, which are limited temporally, it -- it -- it just seems wooden and rigid to say to all of a sudden say, well, it's a public forum for something that will last 30 years for which there is only limited space. It just doesn't make common sense.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How far do you push that? I mean, what about the hypotheticals on the other side? I mean, you have a Statue of Liberty; do we have to have a statue of despotism? Or do we have to put any president who wants to be on Mount Rushmore? How do you answer those?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: How do they do that? What is the -- you mentioned that frequently in your brief, and I'm not sure what formality you have in mind when you say adopt.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, it's frozen into time. Everything up until now is okay, but anything going forward is not?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I thought you said the Government can accept what's there and say that's our speech. But you're challenging the ability to do that going forward.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The other side says that some of these monuments, especially in the Civil War battlegrounds, do indeed show who the donors are.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- Mr. Sekulow says that some of these monuments, notably those in the Civil War battlefields, do show who the donors are. Now is that Government speech or private speech?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So they have to go?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now that the Government converted them, it passes a law saying, what, we -- we adopt this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't it enough that the Government accepts ownership of it and places it on the Government's property? Isn't that a manifestation of the Government's adoption of it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So this case -- your claim would disappear if this town in Utah had passed an ordinance saying we adopt the Ten Commandments Monument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But that's -- I mean, if that's all that's involved here, we're engaging in kind of a -- almost a silly exercise in formality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If we tell them you have got to take the monument down if they don't do it, don't you think they are going to pass that pretty quick?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It depends on what you mean by adopting one version. If it's adopting the version by saying these Ten Commandments are the word of God, that's one thing. If it's adopting it by just saying this is a version of the Ten Commandments that has had a very significant place in the history of the American people.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I wouldn't care what version it was if that's all they're doing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Nor would the Mormons in Utah, I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Let me give you this example. Just by chance yesterday I was taking a walk in a little neighborhood park , and I saw that there was a monument -- a small monument, donated, and it says right on there donated by a private neighborhood association to commemorate a number of people who were killed in the 9-11 attack on the Pentagon. And now if I searched the town records or the county record and I don't find any resolution saying they adopted this monument as their monument, does that mean that if I would like to put up a monument in the park to commemorate loved ones who died, or people who I respect, I have a First Amendment right to do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well what if the situation is a neighborhood association prepared this; they said we'd like to display it in the park; and the county or the town says fine, go ahead and do it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ms. Harris, we -- we need a clear rule here. We -- we can't expect the courts or the cities for that matter to investigate in every case what the degree of the Government's involvement in the -- and what is the degree, 50 percent, 45 percent, 36 years? I mean, we are going to make up a percentage? That's -- that's not the way threshold constitutional questions ought to be resolved or resolvable. We need a clear rule that the cities can rely on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is there an historical basis for that, or you just made it up? You think it would be a good idea? I mean, if that had been the practice over the past 200 years for all of these monuments that -- that, you know, are strewed across the landscape, then I'd say yes, that's probably what the difference is. But I'm not aware that there is any such - - such requirement and any such practice on the part of Government. You're -- you're creating a new world.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It may be a very nice world but it happens not to be the world under which our Constitution has subjected this country.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So that's all right, the first 95 monuments, whoever -- whoever put them up, okay? It's a monument to chocolate chip cookies or whatever else, is that it? First 95?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This is a practical solution to the problem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You're saying the last generation had much more freedom than the present one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can we go back to -- your basic premise is this is a public forum, in any and all instances; and we do have, certainly in the speech area, demonstration area, from time immemorial public parks have been places where people can speak their minds. But I don't know of any tradition that says people can come to the park with monuments and put them up if they will, so long as they meet the equivalent of time, place and manner. So you're making an assumption that from time immemorial, monuments, just like speeches, can be presented by anyone who wants to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If that -- it that is so, what is the point of using the public forum analysis at all?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That -- that may mean that you have the foundation for a -- a speech discrimination argument - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- but that would not be the answer if we were dealing with a -- a traditional public forum in -- in the sense that the Court's cases have used the term.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So it seems to me that your use of public forum is just by kind of remote analogy here, and I -- I'm not sure that it's helping you or would help us if we used it as criterion for decision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, your -- you can stick with it as long as you want; that's what the - - the Tenth Circuit did, but suppose that we were to say that we were unconvinced by the comparison between speeches and parades on the one hand and monuments on the other, so we did not apply the public forum analogy. Would that be the end of your case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but it does all the time. The -- you don't get equal time -- the cigarette companies don't get equal time because the Government says the Surgeon General has determined it is bad for your health. It always suppresses alternative viewpoints.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You will say just the opposite when you come back here to challenge the Ten Commandments monument on -- on Establishment Clause grounds. You will say something like this: Anybody who comes into this park and seeing this monument owned by the Government, on Government land, will think that the Government is endorsing this message. That's what you will say now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now why would it be true there, but it's not true here? Would anybody think that on public land owned by the Government the Government disagrees with this message?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Isn't merely allowing the monument to be built on public property sufficient acceptance? If somebody came up to you and said I'd like to put up a monument in your front yard, and you said sure go ahead, do that, aren't you accepting that -- whatever the monument says, in a sense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but it doesn't -- it doesn't have to do that, say, for time place and manner restrictions for access to a public forum if it really is a public forum. There is something more involved here. This is closer to the case of the individual who says sure, put the McCain sign on -- on my lawn. No one is going to doubt that the person whose house is there is in favor of McCain; and -- and it seems to me we are in the same situation with the monument in the city.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Sure, but when you get the monument - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: We do not -- there is no pervasive understanding or non-pervasive one, I would have thought, in the United States that anyone who wants to display a message in granite in a public park can put it there. No one assumes that. Everyone assumes that, if the granite monument is there, the city or whatever has said, yes, we approve it, put it there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It may create the First Amendment problem, but it seems to me, going back to Justice Alito's question, that the City's decision is a clear adoption of the monument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but even on your own criterion, if the city passes a resolution saying we adopt this, you're still -- you're going to be faced with precisely the content discrimination problem that you're arguing about here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You're basically just arguing for a clear statement rule. I mean, Justice Alito's question, my analogies are suggestive of the fact that there is an affirmative Government act of some indication of approval when it says, yes, you can put the monument here. And what you're arguing for is, well, we want a clearer statement, we want it to say, yes, we really adopt it, it's ours from the heart. And that seems to be the difference between your position and the -- and the position that acceptance of the monument is enough.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, you can - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You can make that distinction. There's no -- I understand the distinction you're making, but because I don't see that that's a distinction that a reasonable member of the public would understand to be implied by the -- or at least to be - - to be raised by the placement of the monument, I don't know why it's a distinction that should be significant for First Amendment purposes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And when Government adopts it, can it at that time specify what it understands the statement to be?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Suppose the resolution of adoption by the City Council just says, "The City Council agrees that this monument of the Eagle Association expresses an idea worthy of the public's attention."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that enough?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You want a signing statement as well as a signature? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does it depend on - - given the focus on public perception, does it depend on the content of the speech? In other words, if you came across a monument and it said, "The Eagles are a lot better than every other organization, you should give money to the Eagles," someone is going to walk by that and say, "Well, that's probably not the City, that's probably the Eagles." But the Eagles, you know, for all the good they do, did not come up with the Ten Commandments, and somebody is going to look at that and say, "That's probably the City." They are not going to look at that and immediately say, "That's what the Eagles believe."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if it's just a statue of George Washington? What kind of a resolution does the city council adopt? "We endorse everything George Washington ever said"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, if - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's right, and I think they would adopt a resolution that says, "We think George Washington is worthy of respect and emulation on the part of our citizens."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If it could say that, why couldn't it say the same thing about the Ten Commandments? "We think the Ten Commandments are worthy of respect and" -- and I wouldn't say "emulation"; I would say "respect and reverence by our citizens."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would that be enough?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know what that means.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It has acquired the memorial. The City has acquired property in this memorial and has agreed for this memorial to be placed in the city park. Period. "We believe that the Ten Commandments which are embodied in this memorial are worthy of respect by the citizens of Pleasant Grove" - - is that enough?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know what that means. You keep saying it, and I don't know what it means.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I would have thought adopting what I said shows that it is adopting the content of the monument insofar as the monument says the Ten Commandments should be respected by the citizens of Pleasant Grove. Is that enough?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or it has to say, "We believe in the Ten Commandments"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't think that's fairly implied by the mere fact that it is there in Pleasant Grove's park and that Pleasant Grove City Council has allowed it to be constructed there? Don't you think that's implicit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Maybe the City doesn't know

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- know what you mean by "We adopt," just as I don't know what you mean by "We adopt."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What do we do -- is this monument suspiciously similar to the one in Texas? And so if the history is the same, you would know that there was -- a big element of this was Cecile B. DeMille trying to promote his movie, The Ten Commandments. So he gave money to the Eagles, and the Eagles put Ten Commandments all over because it would be good for the morality of people, and also it would help promote the movie. All right? Is that true -- is that the actual description here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So -- so if that's the history of it, what does that mean? I mean, where do we go with that? Then this is in fact partly an attempt to promote morality, partly an attempt to be civic, partly an attempt to promote a movie. So, what do we do with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not? Why not? Why - - suppose that there -- there are certain messages that private people had like "eat vitamins" - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- and so they say -- you know, whatever those are; and then somebody comes along with a totally different content, "ride the roller coaster," and they say this part of the park is designed to get healthy children, not put children at risk. So therefore we like messages to eat vitamins, and we don't want messages, "ride the roller coaster." This is all private. It's the -- you know -- now what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So in other words, they - - the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They can't do either.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there any case that says -- can they have playgrounds in the park?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, so we have right in the playground, we have "eat vitamins," "eat your - - clean up all your -- all the food in your plate," "don't throw food at your brother," okay? So -- I mean - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, all private.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because there are various groups that feel that's important; the city says yes, it is; and we don't want things like pull the dog's tail, or - - (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- whatever. So -- so what's wrong with that? Where does the First Amendment forbid that? You promote -- they want in this corner, promoting in the playground good things that they like and not bad ones. Where does it permit it? What's the case that says that the Government couldn't do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Give one and I'll read it. Give me three; I'll read them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But the children's playground isn't the public forum.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I see where you're going. Thank you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you taking this line because you say if the city council votes for it, then the voters can know those people voted to put up the Ten Commandments; we don't like that; so we are going to vote them out? Is that -- what underlies this notion that it isn't good enough for them to approve the placement of the monument, but it has to be some kind of formal declaration?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But it's not disclaiming it here. The Government isn't disclaiming it. And the difference it seems to me between you and your friends on the other side is you want this clear statement. You want a statement -- for example if you took Justice Scalia's statement, that would satisfy you, and it would also be the poison pill in the Establishment Clause. Isn't that what's -- I mean, that's okay with me. I don't see that as an illegitimate object. I was a Van Orden dissenter -- I mean, but isn't that what is driving this?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Sekulow, you have two minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
